You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
```
</target_code>

{
	uint64_t val = 1;
	int ret;

	ret = write(irq_notify_fd, &val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s failed\n", __func__);

explanation:
I report only the metal_log macro because it contains two language extensions that are explicitly documented as compiler extensions: the GCC statement-expression construct ({ ... }) and the use of the token-pasting comma trick (##__VA_ARGS__) to swallow the comma when there are no variadic arguments. These are explicit compiler extensions and require investigation for MISRA Rule 1.2.

Other fragments in the provided code do not show use of compiler language extensions: the function metal_linux_irq_set_enable uses standard C syntax and standard library/syscall usage (write), __func__ is from standard C, the fixed-size integer uint64_t and the array declaration for irqs_enabled are standard C, the METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE invocation is just a macro use but its definition was not provided so there is no evidence in the shown code that it relies on a language extension, and other macros/identifiers (METAL_IRQ_ENABLE, metal_bitmap_set_bit, metal_mutex_acquire/release) are normal identifiers or function-like macros whose shown usage does not itself demonstrate a compiler language extension. Therefore they do not need investigation based on the information given.
